unnormalised: Okay, so, you're planning a trip? That's awesome! I'm telling you, travel is the best. But before you pack your bags and dream of sunsets in Goa, let's talk IDs. You know, the boring but super important stuff.
normalised: Okay, so, you are planning a trip? That is awesome! I am telling you, travel is the best. But before you pack your bags and dream of sunsets in Goa, let us talk I-D's. You know, the boring but super important stuff.

unnormalised: First off, your passport. This is a no-brainer for international travel, obviously. Make sure it's valid for at least 6 months *after* your planned return date. Seriously, check it NOW. Don't be that person stuck at the Mumbai airport because their passport expired yesterday. Passport No. is usually a letter followed by a bunch of numbers like, say, "A12345678". Write that down somewhere safe, both digitally and physically.
normalised: First off, your passport. This is a no-brainer for international travel, obviously. Make sure it is valid for at least six months after your planned return date. Seriously, check it now. Do not be that person stuck at the Mumbai airport because their passport expired yesterday. Passport Number is usually a letter followed by a bunch of numbers like, say, A one two three four five six seven eight. Write that down somewhere safe, both digitally and physically.

unnormalised: Next up: Your Aadhaar card. While it's not a substitute for a passport for international travel, it’s crucial for a lot of things within India. From booking train tickets online (IRCTC account linked, remember?) to checking into hotels, it's your primary Indian ID. Keep a digital copy handy. The Aadhaar number is that 12-digit number, something like, "1234 5678 9012".
normalised: Next up: Your Aadhaar card. While it is not a substitute for a passport for international travel, it is crucial for a lot of things within India. From booking train tickets online (I-R-C-T-C account linked, remember?) to checking into hotels, it is your primary Indian I-D. Keep a digital copy handy. The Aadhaar number is that twelve-digit number, something like, one two three four five six seven eight nine zero one two.

unnormalised: Then there’s your driver’s license. If you're planning on renting a car or a scooter (especially in places like Goa or Rajasthan), you'll need it. Make sure it's valid and keep a copy with you. The license number could look something like "MH-20-2010-0012345". Don't even *think* about driving without one!
normalised: Then there is your driver’s license. If you are planning on renting a car or a scooter (especially in places like Goa or Rajasthan), you will need it. Make sure it is valid and keep a copy with you. The license number could look something like M-H dash twenty dash two thousand ten dash zero zero one two three four five. Do not even think about driving without one!

unnormalised: Flight tickets! If booking online, make sure you download the digital copy of the ticket, with your PNR number clearly visible, something like "PNR: 6XYZ89". Also, airlines may sometimes want to see a secondary form of ID, so keep your PAN card handy too (PAN no. might look like "ABCDE1234F").
normalised: Flight tickets! If booking online, make sure you download the digital copy of the ticket, with your P-N-R number clearly visible, something like P-N-R: six X-Y-Z eight nine. Also, airlines may sometimes want to see a secondary form of I-D, so keep your P-A-N card handy too (P-A-N number might look like A-B-C-D-E one two three four F).

unnormalised: Train tickets, similar to flights. Download or take a screenshot of the e-ticket you receive on SMS/email. Ensure that you keep your PNR number visible for checking. IRCTC PNRs usually consist of 10 digits (ex: 1234567890). If you have booked it directly from the railway counter, keep the physical ticket safely.
normalised: Train tickets, similar to flights. Download or take a screenshot of the e-ticket you receive on S-M-S slash email. Ensure that you keep your P-N-R number visible for checking. I-R-C-T-C P-N-Rs usually consist of ten digits (example: one two three four five six seven eight nine zero). If you have booked it directly from the railway counter, keep the physical ticket safely.

unnormalised: For domestic flights, while some airlines technically accept other forms of ID, I *highly* recommend carrying your Aadhaar or PAN card. It just makes everything smoother. Better safe than sorry, right? And remember, a photo ID is mandatory.
normalised: For domestic flights, while some airlines technically accept other forms of I-D, I highly recommend carrying your Aadhaar or P-A-N card. It just makes everything smoother. Better safe than sorry, right? And remember, a photo I-D is mandatory.

unnormalised: Finally, and this is more for peace of mind, make copies of everything! Scan your passport, Aadhaar, license, and keep them in a separate email folder or cloud storage. You can also leave a set with a trusted family member. If anything gets lost or stolen, you'll have backups. Trust me, it’s worth the effort. Happy travels, y'all!
